Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (statutory frame.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (statutory framework governing leases and landlord-tenant relations)
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (statutory frame.proposition: See Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (statutory framework governing leases and landlord-tenant relations); 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq. (State Sanitary Code, Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation); see also Javins v. First Nattl Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing obligations of landlords and housing code compliance as part of landlord-tenant relationship), which has been persuasive authority referenced in Massachusetts landlord-tenant jurisprudence.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., establishes minimum standards for fitness for human habitation and requires that residential premises be kept free of hazards, have adequate ventilation, and be maintained in a sanitary condition.

Javins v. First Nat\u001ftl Realty Corp..raw_text: Javins v. First Nattl Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First Nat\u001ftl Realty Corp..proposition: See Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (statutory framework governing leases and landlord-tenant relations); 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq. (State Sanitary Code, Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation); see also Javins v. First Nattl Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: See Javins, 428 F.2d at 1075-76; Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984) (discussing landlord obligations); see also out-of-state and federal authorities construing landlord obligations to provide habitable premises and abate hazardous conditions.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion is a leading Vermont case expressly adopting an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases, and it extensively discusses landlords’ obligations to provide and maintain safe, clean, and habitable premises, as well as to remedy hazardous defects. It cites Javins and other out-of-state authorities and follows their reasoning in construing landlords’ duties to abate dangerous and unsanitary conditions. Thus it squarely fits a citation for ‘discussing landlord obligations’ and for out-of-state/federal authority on obligations to provide habitable premises and abate hazardous conditions.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: “Therefore, we now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease… that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation…. Additionally, the implied warranty of habitability covers all latent and patent defects in the essential facilities of the residential unit…. In determining whether there has been a breach… courts should inquire whether the claimed defect has an impact on the safety or health of the tenant.”

Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.proposition: See, e.g., cases and authorities addressing landlord obligations and habitability standards: Javins v. First Nattl Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970); Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 A.D.2d 98 (N.Y. App. Div. 1975) (recognizing landlord duties); Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984); see also Massachusetts decisions and treatises discussing landlord duties and implied covenants (collectively, Authorities).
